May 22, 2016: Fiction
15TH AFFAIR, by James Patterson and Maxine Paetro. (Little, Brown.) When a brutal
murder threatens the domestic happiness of the San Francisco police detective Lindsay
Boxer, she turns for help to the Women's Murder Club.
THE LAST MILE, by David Baldacci. (Grand Central.) In a sequel to “Memory Man,”
Amos Decker, a detective with an extraordinary memory, helps the F.B.I. investigate the
case of a convicted killer who wins a last-minute reprieve.
THE APARTMENT, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte.) Four young women share a Hell’s
Kitchen loft.
EXTREME PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam.) Lucas Davenport, who has left the
Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension, is in Iowa trying to foil a plot to
assassinate a Hillary Clinton-like candidate. The 26th Lucas Davenport thriller.
STAR WARS: BLOODLINE, by Claudia Gray. (Del Rey.) Leia Organa is urged to
become First Senator of the New Republic.
THE NEST, by Cynthia D'Aprix Sweeney. (Ecco/HarperCollins.) Siblings in a
dysfunctional New York family must grapple with a reduced inheritance.
THE GIRL ON THE TRAIN, by Paula Hawkins. (Riverhead.) A psychological thriller set
in the environs of London.
EVERYBODY'S FOOL, by Richard Russo. (Knopf.) We’re back in North Bath, N.Y., in a
sequel to “Nobody’s Fool.”
THE OBSESSION, by Nora Roberts. (Berkley.) A woman is haunted by her father’s
crimes as she tries to pursue love and her work as a photographer.
THE NIGHTINGALE, by Kristin Hannah. (St. Martin's.) Two sisters in World War II
France: one struggling to survive in the countryside, the other joining the Resistance in
Paris.
ALL THE LIGHT WE CANNOT SEE, by Anthony Doerr. (Scribner.) The lives of a blind
French girl and a gadget-obsessed German boy before and during World War II.
ELIGIBLE, by Curtis Sittenfeld. (Random House.) The author of “Prep” and “American
Wife” retells “Pride and Prejudice,” set in the Cincinnati suburbs in the present.
ZERO K, by Don DeLillo. (Scribner.) A billionaire and his son meet at a remote desert
compound dedicated to preserving bodies until they can be returned to life in the future.
AS TIME GOES BY, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster.) Secrets emerge when
a television journalist searching for her birth mother covers the trial of the widow of a
wealthy doctor.
Non-Fiction
THE RAINBOW COMES AND GOES, by Anderson Cooper and Gloria Vanderbilt.
(Harper.) Mother and son discuss their relationship and difficult family history.
GRIT, by Angela Duckworth. (Scribner.) A psychologist and consultant argues that
passion and perseverance are the keys to success.
HAMILTON: THE REVOLUTION, by Lin-Manuel Miranda and Jeremy McCarter.
(Grand Central/Melcher Media.) The libretto of the Grammy- and Pulitzer Prize-
winning musical, annotated by its creator, along with backstage photos, a
production history and interviews with the cast.
BECOMING GRANDMA, by Lesley Stahl. (Blue Rider.) The reporter investigates
how “grandmothering” transforms a woman’s life.
WHEN BREATH BECOMES AIR, by Paul Kalanithi. (Random House.) A memoir
by a physician who received a diagnosis of Stage IV lung cancer at the age of 36.
FIVE EASY THESES, by James Stone. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt.) An executive
and philanthropist discusses five domestic policy problems and offers solutions.
SHOE DOG, by Phil Knight. (Scribner.) A memoir by the founder of Nike.
THE SLEEP REVOLUTION, by Arianna Huffington. (Harmony.) What scientific
research reveals about the dangers of sleep deprivation, and tips for achieving
better sleep habits.
FIVE PRESIDENTS, by Clint Hill with Lisa McCubbin. (Gallery Books.) A retired
Secret Service agent discusses his experience with presidents from Eisenhower to
Ford.
FIRST WOMEN, by Kate Andersen Brower. (Harper.) The 10 first ladies since
1960, based on interviews with White House staff, social secretaries and friends,
by the author of "The Residence."
RED PLATOON, by Clinton Romesha. (Dutton.) The deadly 13-hour battle for a
remote combat outpost in Afghanistan in 2009, by a soldier who received the
Medal of Honor.
RUTHLESS, by Ron Miscavige with Dan Koon. (St. Martin's.) The father of
Scientology's leader criticizes his management of the organization.
BETWEEN THE WORLD AND ME, by Ta-Nehisi Coates. (Spiegel & Grau.) A
meditation on race in America; winner of the National Book Award.
PAUL MCCARTNEY, by Philip Norman. (Little, Brown.) A life, by the author of
"Shout! The Beatles in Their Generation" and "John Lennon."
